direction.raw_text: An opening voice-over plays against dissolving Texas landscapes--broad, bare, and lifeless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are rushing down a rain-swept country road, listening to the rhythmic swish of tires on wet asphalt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The world is full of complainers. But the fact is, nothing comes with a guarantee. I don't care if you're the Pope of Rome, President of the United States, or even Man of the Year--something can always go wrong. And go ahead, complain, tell your problems to your neighbor, ask for help--watch him fly. Now in Russia, they got it mapped out so that everyone pulls for everyone else-- that's the theory, anyway. But what I know about is Texas...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And down here... you're on your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAR NIGHT We are looking at the backs of two people in the front seat-- a man, driving, and a woman next to him. Their conversation will be punctuated by the occasional glare of oncoming headlights and the roar of the car rushing by. The windshield wipers wave a soporific beat. The conversation is halting, awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause, as an oncoming car passes. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another car passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another pause. Another car. Suddenly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...He gave me a little pearl-handled .38 for out first anniversary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Figured I'd better leave before I used it on him. I don't know how you can stand him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm only an employee, I ain't married to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I don't know. Sometimes I think there's something wrong with him. Like maybe he's sick? Mentally?... Or is it maybe me, do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I ain't a marriage counselor. I don't know what goes on, I don't wanna know... But I like you. I always liked you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll figure something out... How come you offered to drive me in this mess?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you. I like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BRAKE Stamped on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Low three-quarters on the car as it squeals to a halt. A car that has been following screeches to a halt just behind it. Both cars sit. Rain patters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close on the man, from behind. He looks at the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't answer. He turns to look back and we see his face, for the first time, in the headlights of the car behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car behind them waiting, patiently. Rain drifts down past its headlights. Finally it pulls out and passes them slowly, their headlights showing it to be a battered green Volkswagon. First the car itself, then its red taillights, disappear into the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cutting between him and the woman, each from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man is uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman is uncomfortable. After a long pause:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I just think maybe I'm making a mistake...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray. Did you mean that, what you said before, or were you just being a gentleman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Abby, I like you, but it's no point starting anything now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I ain't a marriage counselor--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pulling back from RAY and ABBY in bed, making love. The only light is from cars passing along the highway outside. Each sweeping light-by ends in black. The pullback ends in a wide shot of the motel room. The black following the last car lingers. A telephone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MORNING Ray and Abby are asleep. On a nightstand next to the bed, the telephone is ringing. Ray stirs, reaches for the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A silence at both ends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray listens to another silence. It ends with a disconnect. Abby is stirring as Ray gets out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are tracking past a man seated behind a wooden desk, towards an 8 x 10 black-and-white photograph that has just been slapped down on the desktop. The picture is of Abby and Ray in bed together in the motel room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The voice is familiar as that of the narrator whose musings on life in Texas and the Soviet Union opened the movie. We cut to him. He is settling himself into a chair facing the desk. He is LOREN VISSER, a large unshaven man in a misshapen yellow leisure suit. He smiles at the man behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know a place you can get that framed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sits staring down at the photograph. Behind him a window opens on the bar proper. Country-western music filters in from the bar. Marty is not pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He removes a pouch of tobacco from his breast pocket and nonchalantly starts rolling a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lights his cigarette, then slaps his lighter onto the desktop. It is silver, engraved on the top with a lariat spelling out "Loren" in script, and on the side with a declaration that he is "Elks Man of the Year."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty stares down at the photograph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A smoke ring floats into frame from offscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty rises and goes to a safe behind his desk. Visser laughs as he watches Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty, hunched over the standing safe behind his desk, tosses in the photograph and takes out a pay envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser blows another smoke ring, pushes a fat finger through the middle of it, and beams at Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty scales the pay envelope across the desk. It hits Visser in the chest and bounces to the floor. Visser looks stonily down at the envelope; no expression for a beat. Then he roars with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sighing, he leans forward to pick up the envelope. He rises, straightens his cowboy hat, and walks over to a screen door letting out on the bar's back parking lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses at the door, cocks his head, then turns back to the desk and picks up his cigarette lighter. Returning to the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door slams shut behind him. Marty scowls at the back door. After a moment he rises and crosses the office to the window looking out on the bar. Over Marty's shoulder we see the long bar leading up to the window in perpendicular. The camera is tracking forward, past Marty, to frame on the window. A black man is just now vaulting the near end of the bar, over onto the customer side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did you take these for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You called me, I knew they were there, so what do I need these for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know... Call it a fringe benefit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long did you watch her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...They'd just rest a few minutes and then get started again. Quite something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know in Greece they cut off the head of the messenger who brought bad news.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that don't make much sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. It just made them feel better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well first off, Julian, I don't know what the story is in Greece but in this state we got very definite laws about that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Second place I ain't a messenger, I'm a private investigator. And third place--and most important--it ain't such bad news. I mean you thought he was a colored. (he laughs) ...You're always assumin' the worst...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, don't come by here any more. If I need you again I know which rock to turn over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good... "which rock to turn over"... that's very good...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, gimme a call whenever you wanna cut off my head...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: VAULTING MAN Tracking back with him as he lands on the customer side and heads across the bar. This shot, from the other side of the back-office window, reveals the window to be one-way glass mirrored on this side
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the black bartender, is muscular, about 200 pounds, dressed in white pants and a sleeveless T-shirt. He is making his way through the crowd towards the jukebox. Another man stands in front of it examining the selections. He deposits a quarter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meurice shakes his head and punches the selector buttons on the jukebox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Motown song drops. We track behind Meurice as he makes his way back toward the bar. When he reaches it, he claps a couple of people on the shoulder, who make way for him. He vaults back over the top, walks down the bar, and stops in from of an attractive white woman sitting on a bar stool and sipping a brandy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty is approaching from the direction of the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty loses his glare and his gaze drifts over to the woman. After an awkward pause, Meurice clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is unselfconsciously returning Marty's stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meurice walks down the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty studies her for a beat, she studies him, he smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty smiles bleakly. Debra drains her glass as Meurice returns. He sets another Cognac in front of Debra, and a glass of milk in front of Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanders on down the bar; Marty's attention returns to the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty's attention is caught by something down the bar. He half-rises from his stool.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it, hold it. What's tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Friday night is Yankee night. Where're you from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. I'm from Detroit (turning to leave) It's a big city up north with tall buildings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You we telling me about the Ring of Fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, I may be getting in over my head here, I mean you're the geologist, but my theory for what it's worth, you got all these volcanoes and each time one pops it's the equivalent of what, twenty, thirty megatons of TNT?  Enough to light Las Vegas for how long?  How many years? Course, I'm no mathematician but--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he's off tonight. Where was he last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, didn't he call?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Marty, I'd like you to meet an old friend of mine, Debra. Debra, this is Julian Marty, the dude I'm always talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he does come in I'm not here... What were you drinking, Debra?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a very sophisticated palate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give Debra here another drink, and give me the usual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I got tickets for the Oilers and the Rams next week in the Astrodome. Ever sat on the fifty yard line?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't have to. I'll explain what a palate is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't have to. I just wanted to see if you knew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how long have you know Meurice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Meurice is pouring the milk down the sink. He looks innocently up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angry but not knowing what to say. He glances around the bar, sinks slowly back onto his stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty sits staring across the bar for a moment, nods a couple of times at nothing in particular, then looks back at the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty tosses a beer nut into his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debra gives him a level stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both fall silent as Meurice enters frame. He takes a bottle from the bar and pours himself a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty tosses back Meurice's drink, then turns to Debra, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debra watches him go, then turns back to Meurice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Deuce in the corner needs help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell him you have a headache.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't seem to be communicating--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to hustle me. I don't want to be hustled. It's as simple as that. Now that I've communicated, why don't you leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not surprised, the company you've been keeping the last ten years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack Daniels. Don't worry, I'm paying for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The point is we don't serve niggers here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where? (he looks over his shoulder; up and down the bar) ...I'm very careful about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He thinks I'm kidding. Everybody thinks I'm kidding; (as he turns to leave) if Ray comes in I'm not home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. What'd you say your last name was?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DOWN HALLWAY We are following a large German shepherd as it pads down the hall toward a warmly lit room at its end. We hear only the sound of the dog's paws on the hardwood floor, and the faint clicking of billiard balls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a paneled, carpeted room with black leather furniture and a nine-foot billiard table. Various stuffed animal trophies are scattered around the room, including a moose head mounted on one wall. Ray stands alone in the foreground, shooting pool, an unlit cigarette in his mouth. The room is very quiet. In the background the German shepherd enters from the hallway, sits down in a corner, and benignly watches Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is expensively appointed; a brightly lit woman's bedroom. Abby is opening a hinged drawer in a white antique bureau. She pulls out a leather handbag, gropes nervously through its contents, then puts it aside. She crosses the room to a vanity table, takes a purse from underneath, and spills its contents out on top of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray pockets a couple of balls, looks over at the dog, then up at the wall at the far end of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hanging on the wall are a couple of framed photographs of Marty and Abby, taken a long time ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Staring at the pictures. He looks back down at the pool table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby is sitting on a large double bed. She puts aside another purse, rises and crosses the room hurriedly, and pushes back the sliding doors of a long wardrobe closet. The upper shelf is lined with handbags--fifteen or twenty of them. She grabs the first one, looks in, tosses it aside; grabs the second, looks--and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside the purse, a small pearl-handled gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is now standing in front of the pictures on the wall, looking from one to the next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A picture of Abby and Marty standing together on a Gulf beach. Marty is wearing a long velour beach robe, Abby is in a swimming suit. Ray's hand enters frame. He traces a finger down her leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: RAY His head cocked to the side. After a moment his eyes shift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PHOTO DETAIL Of Marty's face. He is staring into the camera, at whoever took the picture. His head is thrown back slightly; he is laughing. From offscreen in the quiet room we hear a static hum and then Abby's voice over an intercom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns from the photograph and walks to an intercom speaker next to the mounted moose's head. He presses the speaker button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He idly takes his unlit cigarette and sticks it in the moose's mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We are looking across a dark, high-ceilinged foyer toward the front door. Ray leans against the doorjamb, in silhouette in the open doorway. He is facing a curved staircase that descends into the foyer. Abby appears at the second-floor landing and starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she reaches the bottom of the stairs:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why d'you wanna leave all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You kidding? I don't wanna leave all this, I just wanna leave Marty...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can stay at my place, I'll drop you there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) Don't go to the bar, Ray. I know him, that ain't a good idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just gotta see a guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The crowd has thinned out. Meurice and Debra are in the foreground. Ray enters from the street and makes his way over to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pours Debra another drink and starts to set one up for Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods at Debra.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Meurice. Sorry I didn't show last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wasn't too busy. You missed a good one, though. This white guy walks in about one o'clock, asks if we have a discount for alcoholics... I tell him to get lost, but Marty's sitting here listening and I can tell he's thinking that maybe it ain't such a bad idea...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Ray, this is Debra. She's a geologist. That's the theory of rocks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not here tonight. Wasn't here last night. He's especially not back in his office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marty is sitting on the stoop that descends from his back office to a graveled back parking lot; he is framed in the open doorway of his brightly lit office. He stares fixedly at something offscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the middle distance a huge incinerator operates full blast. Orange flames lick out the sides; white smoke billows out the top. Two figures in silhouette are chucking garbage in through a large gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind him, in the office, we see the door from the bar open, and Ray entering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty looks over his shoulder, then back toward the furnace. Ray descends the stoop and stands in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty stares past Ray across the parking lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray tenses. There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty still stares at the furnace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finally looks up at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray breaks into a strained half-smile. Marty grins humorlessly back, mimicking Ray's smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs a knee in each hand and leans forward, still looking at Ray. He is becoming only slightly more animated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans back again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray moves forward and Marty's eyes follow him as he approaches. Marty's smile abruptly turns to a look of apprehension. Ray enters frame and brushes past Marty as he walks up the stoop, and crosses the back office toward the bar. Marty relaxes, and his gaze returns to the furnace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray opens the door to the bar and shuts it softly behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Am I fired? You wanna hit me? What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't particularly want to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... if you're not gonna fire me I might as well quit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. Suit yourself. (still staring fixedly at the furnace) ...Having a good time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I don't like this kind of talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what'd you come here for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (no more conciliation) You owe me for two weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. She's an expensive piece of ass...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You get a refund though, if you tell me who else she's been sluicing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want that money. If you wanna tell me something, fine--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're you, a fucking marriage counselor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're you smiling at--I'm a funny guy, right, I'm an asshole? No, no, that's not what's funny. What's funny is her. What's funny is that I had you two followed because, if it isn't you, she's been sleeping with someone else...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What's really going to be funny is when she gives you that innocent look and says, What're you talking about, Ray, I haven't done anything funny...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...But the funniest thing to me right now is that you think she came back here for you--*that's* what's funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Come on this property again and I'll be forced to shoot you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CEILING FAN At the cut the music and all other bar noise drops out. We hear only the rhythmic whir of the fan. We tilt down from the ceiling fan to frame Marty, tilted back in his desk chair, staring up at the fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE OFFICE Meurice is standing in the door to the bar. Far behind him we can see Debra waiting in the dimly lit, deserted bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meurice pauses in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meurice and Debra can be heard leaving the bar. Marty looks down at the telephone in front of him on the desk, then picks up the receiver and dials. He tilts back in the chair and stares back up at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...I thought you were dead. Going home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I think I'll stay right here in hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to leave) Kind of a bleak point of view there, isn't it Marty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I don't want that asshole near my money. I don't even want him in the bar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We get a lot of assholes in here, Marty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The ceiling fan, turning slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the foreground Ray sits behind the wheel of his parked car, slumped back against the seat. He is staring at his one- story bungalow, in which a couple of lights are burning. Inside we can faintly hear his telephone ringing. It rings for a long time.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: RAY'S BUNGALOW FROM INSIDE RAY'S CAR

direction.raw_text: THE RINGING TELEPHONE Abby's hand enters frame, hesitates, then after another ring picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The is no answer. From the other end we hear only the rhythmic whir of a ceiling fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty listens. He says nothing, still tilted back in his chair, staring at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby listens. She shifts the phone to her other ear, listening hard to the sound of the fan. There is another long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone goes dead just as we hear the front door opening. Abby looks up as she cradles the phone. Ray is standing in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray leans against the door and folds his arms, watching Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby looks at him, puzzled. After an uncomfortable pause:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby shifts uneasily, looking at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray walks toward the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: On the phone. Was it for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, he didn't say anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. So how do you know it was a he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) You got a girl--am I screwing something up by being here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I can find a place tomorrow, then I'll be outta your hair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that's what you want to do, then you oughta do it. You, uh... you want the bed or the couch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... the couch would be all right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can sleep on the bed if you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I'm not gonna put you out of your bed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't be putting me out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Still tilted back in his chair, Marty stares glumly at the ceiling. The bar itself is completely still except the rhythmic whir of the fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A CEILING FAN Turning slowly. We tilt down from the fan to frame Abby, lying under a sheet on Ray's couch, staring up at the fan in the darkened living room. The room is still. We hear only the whir of the fan and the distant sound of crickets. Abby turns her head, looking offscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ray of light slants up the hallway from the direction of the bedroom. The light is snapped off, leaving the hallway in darkness. We hear a faint cough and the creaking of bedsprings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray lies in bed, staring at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE LIVING ROOM  FROM THE HALLWAY Abby sits up. She stands and walks across the moonlit room toward the hallway. We pull her back down the hall toward the bedroom. She pauses in the bedroom doorway and looks down toward the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray in bed, his eyes closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pull her as she enters the room, then tilt down with her as she hesitantly sits on the edge of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot, Ray asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Framed against a moonlit window from the shoulders up. There is a long pause. Ray's hand enters frame and pulls Abby down out of frame onto the bed. We hold on the moonlit window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PRE-DAWN Through the window the slow dissolve gradually defines the front lawn and the street beyond in the flat pre-dawn light. Abby rises into frame and quietly gets out of bed. The camera tracks behind her as she walks up the hallway into the living room. We follow her across the living room and move into a close shot on her hand as she reaches into her purse and withdraws a small plastic compact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ABBY She flips open the compact, then, hearing something, looks up, squinting across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the shadows at the far end of the room we can just see two pointed ears and a glittering pair of eyes. The German shepherd is panting softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she peers into the shadows, her face reflected in the mirror of the open compact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the mirror something moves just behind her. Abby starts to turn. Marty's hand clamps over her mouth from behind. His other hand circles her waist. Abby struggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty's hand drops from her waist to her thighs and slides under the robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still holding her from behind, Marty forces her down on her knees. Abby's cries are muffled by the hand clamped over her mouth. Marty shoots a glance down the dark hallway. There is no movement. Abby's hand is groping forward out of frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ABBY'S PURSE She upsets it. The contents spill out, among them a small pearl-handled revolver. Her hand gropes for the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty yanks her to her feet, looking down the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is dragging her to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes her through the screen door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The neighborhood is deserted and still. The streetlamps are still on. Marty and Abby stumble down the front stoop onto the lawn. His hand is still clamped over her mouth. She reaches up, grabs a finger, and bends it back. We hear the bone snap. Marty screams. His hand drops. His other hand cuffs her on the side of the head, spinning her around. Marty is now clutching his broken finger with his good hand. Abby kicks him in the groin. He sinks to his knees, drops forward on one hand, and vomits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is coming out the door, hitching up his pants. In his right hand he hold Abby's pearl-handled revolver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly gets to his feet, looking at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has backed away from Marty and now stands on the lawn, breathing heavily. She looks from Ray to Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Backing toward his car, a Cadillac parked at curbside, still looking at Ray. He turns to get into the car. The German shepherd lopes across the lawn and takes a clean leap into the car through the open window on the passenger side. Marty turns the ignition. The engine coughs and dies. He tries again; it starts. The car roars up the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching the car. He looks at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still panting. Up the street we can hear Marty's car alternately racing and stopping, shifting in and out of gear. His engine rumble starts to grow louder again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the background we see Marty's car roar by in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Like to have seen his face when he found the dead end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moving past a row of cars parked on an overlook near the top of the mountain. Below we can see the lights of the city of Austin. The lot is littered with beer cans. We hear the sound of rock music coming from various car radios. Several teenagers lean against cars drinking beer; inside the cars we can see the vague forms of others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His friends laugh.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey mister, how'd you break your pussyfinger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ignoring the laughter as he walks past the cars, apparently looking for someone. His right index finger is taped up in an aluminum splint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the end of a row of cars we see a green Volkswagon bug. Leaning against the hood is Visser, still dressed in his rumpled yellow suit. He is smoking a cigarette, talking to a sixteen-year-old girl in shorts and a tube top. When he notices Marty:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl drifts off. Marty enters frame and Visser turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser open the back door of the car. Marty ignores the invitation, walks around to the front on the passenger side and gets in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the girl) Sorry sweetheart, my date is here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...She saw me rolling a cigarette and thought it was marijuana. (he laughs) I guess she thought I was a swinger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Visser gets into the driver's seat. A small topless doll is suspended from the rearview mirror. Visser gives it a tap. As it swings back and forth two small lights, one behind each breast, blink on and off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both men sit watching the doll intently. Finally Marty reaches up and stops its swinging with the rounded end of his splint. Visser eyes the splint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty is silent, but Visser is in a good mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Overcome by laughter. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser shrugs, lights up another cigarette with his fraternally inscribed lighter and drops the lighter onto the dashboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty doesn't answer. Finally Visser laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser eyes him, still smiling. Finally he shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty's shoulders slump. He seems less tense, almost relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are staring at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser laughs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and gazes out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He falls silent again, still staring out the window In the closeness of the car Marty is starting to sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty is slumped in his seat, not responding to the fact that Visser has just ended the conversation. Finally he rouses himself and gets out of the car, leaving Visser staring at the door he has left open behind him. After a moment we hear Marty's footsteps approaching again, and he leans back into the open door with an afterthought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These words are difficult to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men look at each other. Marty leaves. After a moment, Visser leans over to grab the handle of the still open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door slams.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (genially) Stick your finger up the wrong person's ass?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know a friend of mine broke his hand a while back. Put in a cast. Very next day he takes a fall, protects his bad hand, falls on his good one, breaks that too. So now he's got two busted flippers and I say to him "Creighton, I hope your wife loves you. 'Cause for the next five weeks you cannot wipe your own goddamn ass..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...That's the test, ain't it? Test of true love--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (settling down) ...Well, if the pay's right and it's legal I'll do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If the pay's right I'll do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's, uh... it's in reference to that gentleman and my wife. The more I think about it the more irritated I get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Well how irritated are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Gee, I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me what you want me to do or is it a secret?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I'm not--this isn't a joke here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say that. (a pause) Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, uh... this wouldn't interest you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say that. All I said was you're an idiot. Hell, you been thinking about it so much it's driving you simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten thousand dollars I'll give you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm supposed to do a murder--two murders--and just trust you not to go simple on me and do something stupid. I mean real stupid. Now why should I trust you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobering) The money. Yeah. That's a right smart of money...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...In Russia they make only fifty cents a day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (abruptly) I want you to go fishing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go down to Corpus for a few days. Get yourself noticed. I'll give you a call when it's done... You just find a way to cover that money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take care of the money, you just make sure those bodies aren't found... There's a...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...If you want, there's a big incinerator behind my place...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under his breath) Sweet Jesus, you are disgusting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EMPTY APARTMENT  NIGHT The apartment is dark. We are looking across a shadowy floor towards a large window, through which cold blue street light shines. Through the window we can see the facade of the building across the street; we are three or four floors up. We can hear the animated, accented voice of an Hispanic woman approaching the apartment from the hallway behind us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A crack of light shoots across the floor as we hear the apartment door open behind us. A figure enters frame. As it crosses into the shaft of light we see that it is Abby. She moves across the dark apartment, in silhouette against the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An overhead light is switched on and the room is bathed in light. Several feet from Abby, an old man in a dirty undershirt is asleep on a cot. Abby starts. The old man grumbles, slowly sits up, squints. With the light, the window behind Abby has become a mirror of the entire room, in which we now see the matronly Landlady standing by the wall switch. The Landlady roars at the old man in Spanish. The man glowers at her. The Landlady looks back at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We follow Abby as she accompanies the landlady back into the short hallway-entrance foyer. Abby glances back at the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Landlady laughs cheerfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures to a kitchen alcove on the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and throws a few more barbs in Spanish back toward the old man, then opens a door on the right side of the foyer and enters the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She flushes the toilet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She bustles out of the bathroom and takes the two short steps back into the main room. She gestures expansively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives one vigorous stomp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man is now sitting on the edge of the bed, smoking a cigarette, looking for a place to put the ash. The Landlady snaps at him again in Spanish, and is again cheerful as she turns back to address Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks to the apartment door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks out and shuts the door. The room is quiet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) --big windows, paneleen and everytheen. So you want, like your own place? Like a Town House?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No one will bother you here, sweetie--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure this is... Are you sure this apartment is vacant?... Mrs. Esteves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And here we are back in the liveen room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I was just esplaineen to him that he moved out of here yesterday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You look around. Don't mind Mr. Garcia; he use do be my brother-in- law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ABBY Staring at the door. She looks at Mr. Garcia, looks nervously around the apartment. She looks back at Mr. Garcia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MR. GARCIA Staring vacantly at Abby. He blows a stream of smoke across the room. The ash falls off his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hunched over the public address microphone in his small cubicle of exhortation, is the middle-aged strip-bar barker. Years of service in the bar have left his exhortations depressingly bereft of conviction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How 'bout it, gentlemen, let's show out appreciation for Lorraine up there, a registered nurse from Bolton, Texas, how 'bout it gentlemen, yeah...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Meurice is one of a line of men sitting at the bar, all looking intently at the same point off left. All of the men except Meurice are conservatively dressed and apparently well-to-do. An audio loop is blaring a bump-and-grind version of "Yellow Rose of Texas," punctuated by the crash of cymbals and the thumping of toms. Abby enters and sits into an empty chair next to Meurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meurice continues to stare intently off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of the heads at the bar start to swivel, including Meurice's. A couple of patrons hurriedly snatch their drinks off the bar. In the extreme foreground a stripper dances on the top of the bar into frame. We crop her just above her white high- heeled cowboy boots and her bare calves. The conversation continues with Abby looking at Meurice, but Meurice and everyone else at the bar looking up at a point somewhere above the stripper's calves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stripper drops a white leatherette vest onto the bar in the foreground. The audience cheers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two sheriff-star pasties drop onto the bar. The audience cheers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like the state legislature is out of session.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought this is where they met.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen Meurice, you're gonna help me with a problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna keep an eye on Marty and Ray, make sure nothing happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Ever occur to you, Abby, that maybe I'm the wrong person to ask?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Into his microphone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not sit on our wallets, gentlemen. Lorraine is up there dancing her heart out, and if you let that cash money set on your hip, you might just as well be broke...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She is rising to leave; he is still staring off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old-west gunbelt hits the bar. The audience roars.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any time. But you don't have to worry about a thing for a while. Marty went down to Corpus yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Into his microphone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And remember, gentlemen, we're always here, two to two, A.M. to P.M., three hundred and sixty-four days and Christmas, God willing and the creek don't rise...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The room is dark. We are looking across the room toward a moonlit window. Beyond, across the lawn, the lamplit street is empty. Suddenly Abby sits bolt upright into frame from the bed below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Offscreen we hear Ray stirring in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby twists around to look down at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls her down out of frame and we hold on the window and the empty lamplit street. Then Abby rises back into frame, in silhouette against the window, looking down at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She taps herself on the forehead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I could've sworn I heard something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew it. 'Cause we wouldn't have heard anything if it was him. He's real careful. Fact is, he's anal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, he told me once himself. He said to me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ..."In here, Abby. In here... I'm anal."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: RAY Looking up at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ABBY Framed against the window, looking down at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drops down onto the bed out of frame. The camera holds on the window through which we see the empty lamplit street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rises back up into frame, in silhouette against the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Me on the other hand, I got lots of personality...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Marty always said I had too much. 'Course he was never big on personality...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...He sent me to a psychiatrist to see if he could calm me down some.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Psychiatrist said I was the healthiest person he'd ever met, so Marty fired him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sleepily) ...I don't know if you can fire a psychiatrist, exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I didn't see him anymore, I'll tell you that much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: RAY His eyes half-closed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I said, Marty, how come you're anal and I gotta go to the psychiatrist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ABBY Framed against the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray's hand rises into frame and coaxes Abby back down onto the bed, revealing, through the window, a green Volkswagon now parked at curbside on the lamplit street. We hear the rustle of sheets. As we hold on the window, we begin to hear the faint, distant sound of metal scraping against metal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. He's like you, he doesn't say much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Except when he doesn't say things they're usually nasty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you don't they're usually nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh? Oh, yeah, I guess. Mm-hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We track down the dark hallway into the living room. As the camera advances the sound of the scraping becomes louder. We are moving across the living room up to the front door of the bungalow. The scraping is louder still as we finally frame on a close shot of the doorknob, which is jiggling ever so slightly. We hear a click as the lock finally releases. The door swings slowly open, revealing a man's hand on the outside doorknob. We follow the hand as the man advances slowly and quietly across the living room. Abby's purse comes into frame, sitting on a bureau; next to it is a large tote bag. The hand rummages through the tote bag briefly, then the purse. The man withdraws Abby's pearl- handled revolver. He breaks it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE MAN'S FACE It is Visser. As we hear a click offscreen, his face glows a dim orange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His right holds the revolver, cylinder open, inside the purse. His left holds his cigarette lighter as he inspects the chamber. Three of the holes glint silver, the other three are black--empty. We hear the faint creaking of bedsprings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LIVING ROOM Visser cocks his head, listening, and looks down the hallway. He takes a couple of quiet steps across the living room and, as the camera tracks up to him, opens the back door of the bungalow. We follow him outside onto the lawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We track behind him as he rounds the corner of the house and approaches the open window to Ray's bedroom. He slows, moves more cautiously, then sinks to his knees under the window. As he reaches into his breast pocket the camera continues tracking up to and over him, finally framing his POV through the window. On the bed inside we can dimly see Abby and Ray, asleep. We have been hearing a faint rumble, becoming louder and louder as if approaching from a distance. Just as the rumble becomes deafening a sudden bright flash of light illuminates the room, seeming to polarize the image of Abby and Ray in bed, and we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PHONE BOOTH DAY A huge truck roars by on the street behind Visser, and with it the deafening rumble recedes. It is a painfully bright day. Visser stands sweating in the phone booth with the receiver pressed to his ear. We hear the phone ringing at the other end. Finally, it is picked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser forces a chuckle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, what is it? Is it done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: TWO STRINGS OF FISH Being plopped down onto Marty's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R  THE OFFICE Visser sits facing the desk. He lights himself a cigarette and sets the lighter down on the desk in front of him. Marty settles, fidgeting, into the chair behind it. The bar is quiet, shut down. We hear only the whir of a fan somewhere offscreen. Marty and Visser are lit by a lamp on the desk between them. Light streams into the room from a bathroom in the background. Visser is looking at the dead fish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty half-rises from his seat and picks up one of the strings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops them on Visser's side of the desk. Visser's head draws back: he was only being polite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser hands a 9 x 12 envelope across the desk. Marty stares at it for a moment, then quickly bends back the flap and takes out an 8 x 10 photograph.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just the ten thousand'll be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got something to show me first?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is a black-and-white shot of Abby and Ray in Ray's bed. The sheet that partially covers them is pocked with three dark bullet holes and is stained with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Staring dully down at the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE TOP OF THE DESK Visser is pushing the fish away from his side of the desk with the eraser end of a pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking at the picture. He traces the outline of Abby's body with his finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty slips the picture back into its 9 x 12 envelope. His face is pale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises and heads for the bathroom, still clutching the envelope.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...What did you do with the bodies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's taken care of. The less you know about it the better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: VISSER As his eyes follow Marty's exit. The bathroom door doesn't close all the way; a narrow shaft of light slices the office from the bare bulb in the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to look across the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The standing safe behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking at the safe. Beads of sweat have popped out on his forehead. He fans himself with his cowboy hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a toilet flush offscreen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and you did say somethin' about some money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MARTY'S OFFICE As he reenters the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser stares dully down at the desktop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Something I got to ask you, Marty. I've been very very careful. Have you been very very careful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CORNER OF THE OFFICE Marty is hunched over the open safe, still holding the envelope. Blocking Visser's view of the safe with his body, he slides the picture of Abby's and Ray's corpses from under the envelope into the safe, then withdraws two packets of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shuts the safe and spins the dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks across the room and throws the money and the envelope down on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visser looks from the money down at his hands. They are sweating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wipes his hands on his pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty sits and props his booted feet up on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods toward the envelope on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes the money across the desk with his boot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hand comes out with a gun pointing at Marty and--BAM--he fires, an orange lick of flame spurting from the gun. Both men sit frozen. Visser's hand is the only thing that moved.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be absurd, I wasn't about to tell anyone...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...This is an illicit romance--we've got to trust each other to be discreet...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't say that. Your marriages don't work out so hot...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's taken care of. The less you know about it the better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I just made a call about that. It'll look fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) I must've gone money simple. This kind of murder...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you shouldn't have done it. Can't have it both ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reaching into his coat) Nah, I trust ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MARTY Staring at Visser. After the gun blast we hear only the whir of the fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VISSER Staring at Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARTY  OVER VISSER'S SHOULDER His eyes are now shut. Otherwise he hasn't moved. A blood stain is growing on the front of his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE OFFICE The two face each other across the desk. Visser's gun is still trained on Marty. After a moment Visser starts fanning himself again with his cowboy hat. The only movement in the frame is the slow back- and-forth of the yellow hat, rhythmically in and out of shadow as it catches and loses the light from the desk lamp. There is a long pause. Finally one of Marty's feet slips from the desk and hits the floor with a THUD. Visser lays the gun on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VISSER As he reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a handkerchief. He wipes his forehead, then picks up the gun and wipes it off. He leans down with the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE GUN As Visser places it deliberately on the floor near the desk. It is Abby's pearl-handled revolver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Visser straightens up in the foreground. From our head-on angle shooting across the desk we can see the bright metallic glint of Visser's cigarette lighter underneath the dead fish. Visser's hands move over the near part of the desk, picking up the money and the 9 x 12 picture envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE OFFICE As Visser turns from the desk and walks across the room out of frame. We hear the back door opening.

direction.raw_text: The door slams shut. The only sound is the whir of the fan. A pause. The camera tracks slowly forward, tilting down to keep Marty and the desktop centered in frame. As the camera moves the noise of the fan grows louder. When Marty's body and the desk are directly beneath us, the blades of the ceiling fan cut across the immediate foreground and effect a:

direction.raw_text: It is completely still. We are looking from the bar, across the dark empty floor, toward the pebbled windows at the front of the building that catch a hard blue light from the streetlamps outside. The jukebox in the middle distance glows in the darkness. A pair of headlights catches the pebbled glass and grows brighter as we hear a car pull up to the bar and stop. We hear a car door open and shut, then the sound of feet on gravel. A huge shadow appears on the pebbled glass as the figure crosses in front of the headlights. The man tries the door, finds it locked, and walks back in front of the headlights to cup his hands at a window. He walks back to the door, and a moment later it swings open--framing him in the doorway in silhouette. We follow him as he moves across the floor, behind the bar and up to the cash register. He switches on a small fluorescent light clamped to the top of the cash register. It is Ray. He punches a key and the register rings open. He lifts up the empty cash drawer and takes some papers from underneath it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he flips through the papers; bills, receipts, no money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he finishes flipping through the papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slips them back under the cash drawer and slams the register shut. Turning from the register he glances around the bar, the pauses, noticing something.

direction.raw_text: Light is spilling out from under the door to Marty's office.

direction.raw_text: As he starts across the floor to Marty's office.

direction.raw_text: He reaches the door and knocks sharply. No answer. He turns the knob.

direction.raw_text: The door is locked. We hear the muffled whir of the ceiling fan inside. A pause. Ray withdraws a ring of keys from his pocket and uses one on the door. The door swings open. Over his shoulder we see Marty, still at his desk, his back to us. On foot is still propped on the desk.

direction.raw_text: No answer. Ray stumbles toward Marty. He stumbles slightly and we hear the sharp blast of a gun and the sound of something metallic skating across the floor. Ray, startled, steadies himself against the desk, then studies Marty.

direction.raw_text: There is a dark pool of blood under Marty's chair.

direction.raw_text: He looks back up at Marty, then walks behind his chair and throws a wall switch. The room is bathed in light. His eyes still on Marty, Ray crosses behind the desk.

direction.raw_text: Still moving. He looks away from Marty, scans the floor. He gets down on his hands and knees and peers under the safe.

direction.raw_text: There is a glinting silver circle in the darkness under the safe. It is the business end of the revolver that Ray half- stumbled over, half-kicked.

direction.raw_text: Still on his hands and knees. He reaches in and we hear a rattle as he gropes under the safe. He withdraws the gun, looks at it.

direction.raw_text: It is Abby's revolver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a long moment he doesn't move. Then, slowly, he starts to get up.

direction.raw_text: R The desk, Marty behind it, Ray straightening behind him. Ray looks from the gun to Marty, slowly sets the gun down on the desk. A pause. He begins to hoist Marty from the chair. There is noise from the bar, as of someone entering. Ray reacts.

direction.raw_text: Separating the bar and back office. Ray hurries to it.

direction.raw_text: Footsteps approach the door.

direction.raw_text: We hear a record drop on the jukebox and a Motown song blares. Ray crosses to Marty's chair and takes off his nylon windbreaker. He stoops down and tries to mop up the pool of blood with his windbreaker. This isn't going to work. He rises and walks over to the bathroom, the windbreaker dripping blood.

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What day is it today, Angie?

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Tuesday night is ladies' night. All your drinks are free.

direction.raw_text: FAUCET The song continues faintly in the background. The faucet is turned on and Ray's hand enters frame, holding a dirty white towel under the stream of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The song continues in the background. Ray's hand enters frame holding the balled-up towel. His windbreaker is wrapped inside. The camera follows as he pushes it across the trail of dripped blood to the pool of blood under Marty's chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARTY He still has not moved. Ray rises into frame and takes him under the armpits. He notices something on the desk in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE GUN ON THE DESK Ray's hand enters frame and picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARTY'S COAT POCKET Ray's hand enters frame and slips the gun into Marty's pocket. Marty is hoisted up.
direction.name: direction

There are three or four wooden steps going down from the back door to the small gravel parking lot in back. Ray backs down the stairs; Marty's feet THUMP-THUMP-THUMP down the stairs after him. The rear door of Ray's car is open. Ray heaves in Marty's torso. Marty's legs rest on the ground outside the car. Ray takes an ankle in each hand and pushes.

location: BACK OF THE BAR / PARKING LOT

direction.raw_text: RAY As he shuts the door. He looks up across the parking lot.

direction.raw_text: TOWARD INCINERATOR We are looking down on Ray's car as the camera tracks behind it towards the incinerator. At the cut the roar of the incinerator is suddenly louder. It grows louder still as we approach it. Ray's car draws even with the incinerator without slowing or stopping. The wadded-up towel is chucked out of his window into the fire. We hold on the fire as Ray's car rolls on out of frame.

direction.raw_text: As he drives down a deserted country highway. We hear the rhythmic sound of the wheels clomping over asphalt. The radio is broadcasting a fundamentalist's sermon, periodically interrupted by static. Ray is sweating.

dialogue.raw_text: --so there were three signs, the second of which is Famine, this famine which I have already pointed out is devastatin' Africa and the Indian subcontinent. And the third of these signs is earthquakes. Now I don't know why he threw that in but if you talk to a geologist, and I've talked to many, he'll tell you that earthquake activity--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marty is lying inert.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: --has increased almost eighty percent in the past two years, and what's more, in two years' time we'll be experiencin' what's knows as the Jupiter Effect--

dialogue.raw_text: --wherein all the planets of the known universe will be aligned up causin' an incredible buildup of destructive gravitational force. Now in Matthew Chapter Six, Verse Eighteen the Lord out and tells us that these are the signs by which we shall know that He is at our door. There are many good people disagree with me, but it's my belief that this Antichrist is alive today and livin' somewhere in Europe, in that ten- nation alliance I spoke of, bein' groomed for his task--

direction.raw_text: RAY His jaw tightens. He whips his head toward the back seat. His head snaps forward again and he slams on the brakes. The car screeches to a halt.

direction.raw_text: . HIGHWAY LONG SHOT  THE CAR As Ray's door flies open. He is bolting from the car. The camera, at waist level, tracks toward him as he races out into the field that abuts the highway. Fifty yards in he finally stops, panting, framed from a low angle. His breath vaporizes in the crisp night air. We hear only his breath and the chirring of crickets. He is looking back toward the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LONG SHOT  THE CAR Standing abandoned on the shoulder of the deserted highway. Its headlights cast a lonely beam up the road. No movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His panting slows. He is in a cold sweat. After a long moment, he starts walking slowly, reluctantly, back toward the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TRACKING Toward the car. Still no sign of movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slows as he draws up to the back of the car. He looks in the back window.

direction.raw_text: BACK SEAT OF THE CAR It is empty. The door on the highway side is ajar.

direction.raw_text: No reaction. He walks around the back of the car onto the highway. He looks up the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty is crawling up the road on his hands and knees, leaving a trail of blood. The headlights of Ray's car give a fantastically long shadow.

direction.raw_text: Still no reaction. He gets into the driver's seat and stares through the windshield as he gropes for the ignition key.

direction.raw_text: Marty, crawling.

direction.raw_text: He throws the car into drive, looks at his target, thinks-- decides. He pulls the key out of the ignition and goes around to the trunk of the car. He opens it and pulls out a shovel.

direction.raw_text: From in front. The headlights glare behind him. His breath vaporizes. In the background Ray is walking toward him, dragging the shovel, which scrapes along the asphalt. As Ray moves into the foreground and turns to face Marty only his lower legs and the shovel are in frame. The shovel rises out of frame.

direction.raw_text: RAY Both hands hold the shovel tensed over his shoulder. He stares down at Marty. A long pause. We hear a distant rumble.

direction.raw_text: RAY'S FEET Inches away from Marty. Marty's hand slides forward and wraps around one of Ray's ankles.

direction.raw_text: He shudders. He adjusts his grip on the shovel. The rumble grows louder.

direction.raw_text: Looks up from Marty. The rumble grows louder.

result.heading: FROM ACROSS THE ROOF OF THE CAR

direction.raw_text: RAY  FROM ACROSS THE ROOF OF THE CAR As he slams the back door shut. He presses himself against the side of the car. Headlights glare over him; the truck roars by just behind him.

direction.raw_text: . OPEN FIELD FULL SHOT  RAY'S CAR Sudden quiet at the cut. We are looking at Ray's car in profile, parked in the middle of a deserted field. From offscreen we hear the sound of a shovel biting into earth. We track laterally down the car, along the beam of its headlights, to finally frame Ray as he climbs out of the shallow grave he has just finished digging. He plants the shovel and walks back to the car.

In the foreground Ray is sitting in the open door of his car, smoking a cigarette. His gaze is fixed on a spot offscreen.

direction.raw_text: A house. Quite near by. The house and its perfect green rectangle of lawn are set incongruously in the middle of the open field.

direction.raw_text: Staring, without emotion. He takes one last, fierce drag on the cigarette, then flicks it away. He takes the shovel, walks over to the grave and stares at it for several seconds, shovel clasped firmly in both hands. He walks back to the car.

direction.raw_text: House, car and grave. Ray throws the shovel into the car, gets in, and turns the ignition. The engine coughs weakly and dies. He tries again. Same result. One more time. The engine coughs, sputters, and fires to life. The car runs over the grave and rattles on across the rutted field towards the highway in the distance.

A moment later Ray's dirt-caked hand comes into frame and gently brushes a wisp of hair back for Abby's face. We hear Ray walk across the apartment and a moment later the sound of water running. Abby stirs. She looks offscreen.

direction.raw_text: RAY Standing in the doorway to the bathroom. He is wiping his hands on a towel.

direction.raw_text: Ray swings a chair out and sits down behind a table at the far end of the room. He leans back and props his legs up on the table. He is staring across the room at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we hear the click of a pull-string the camera is dropping: down past an orange safe light, down the length of the string, down to a metal darkroom tray where two short strips of negative are burning. Visser's hand and yellow sleeve cuff (now orange) enter frame, with an 8 x 10 black-and-white photograph. The photograph is dropped into the tray. As it burns we see that it is the same picture of Abby's and Ray's "corpses" as Visser showed Marty, except that in this print the bullet holes and blood are less convincingly brushed in. Another print is dropped into the tray and ignites. In this one we see bullet holes but no blood. A third print is dropped in and ignites. It is the original undoctored shot of Abby and Ray asleep in bed. Visser's hands enter frame holding the picture-envelope that he took away from Marty's office. Visser rips it in half and is about to drop it into the tray, but stops abruptly. There is posterboard, not a photograph, peeking out of the torn envelope. Visser's hands pull the two halves of the placard from the envelope and fit them together. The stenciled 8 x 10 placard says: "All Employees Must Wash Hands Before Resuming Work."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VISSER Staring at the placard in disbelief. After a moment his hand rises into frame to deposit a cigarette in his mouth. His hand drops back down, groping in a pocket. His hand jumps back into frame, empty; he thumps at his breast pockets; he can't find his lighter. He wheels and exits frame. The light snaps off. A door slams shut.

direction.raw_text: RAY He has dozed off in his chair. Offscreen we hear a door slam, and his eyes open.

direction.raw_text: Emerging from the bathroom. Her voice has a flat echo in the bare apartment.

direction.raw_text: The chair grates back as he stands up and looks vaguely around the room.

direction.raw_text: He pauses, seemingly at a total loss.

direction.raw_text: Ray is walking to the window. Sunlight streams in around him.

direction.raw_text: He stoops down to look through a pile of clothes by the window.

direction.raw_text: Ray's head snaps around. Staring at her he slowly rises to his feet and then remains still.

direction.raw_text: Abby, startled, can't contain her agitation anymore.

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you get into bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (groggy) I didn't think I could sleep. I'm surprised you could. Are you all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I just wanted to let you know that everything was all right. I took care of everything. Now all we have to do is keep our heads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know about it, Abby. I went to the bar last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...He didn't see me, though. Nobody saw me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cleaned it all up, but that ain't important...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What's important is what we do now; I mean we can't go around half- cocked. What we need is some time to think about this, figure it out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Anyway, we got some time now. But we gotta be smart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Abby, never point a gun at anyone unless you're gonna shoot him. And when you shoot him you better make sure he's dead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...because if he's not dead he's gonna get up and try and kill you.

dialogue.raw_text: ...That's the only thing they told us in the service that was worth a goddamn--Where the hell's my windbreaker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That ain't important. What's important is that we did it. That's the only thing that matters. We both did it for each other...

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogue.raw_text: ... I mean what're you talking about, Ray? I haven't done anything funny.

dialogue.raw_text: (rapidly) Ray, I mean you ain't even acting like yourself. First you call me at five in the A.M. saying all kinds of nice things over the telephone and then you come charging in here scaring me half to death without even telling me what it is I'm supposed to be scared of. I gotta tell you it's extremely rattling.

direction.raw_text: Still worked up.

In the foreground Visser sits in a chair with the cradled telephone in his lap, facing the front door, which stands open in the background. The contents of Abby's tote bag lie strewn on the bureau next to Visser. Her purse is not there. After a moment Visser rouses himself and starts to sweep the articles back into the tote bag.

direction.raw_text: . MEURICE'S APARTMENT  DAY LOW WIDE SHOT  LIVING ROOM It is dark, lit only by the morning light leaking in around the drawn blinds. It is a small modern apartment such as one sees in large apartment complexes--shag carpeting, built-in bar. In the extreme foreground the small red "Power" light of a telephone answering machine glows in the darkness. The front door opens in the background, spilling bright sunlight. Meurice stoops down, picks up two newspapers, enters, and shuts the door. He walks toward the camera and his hand enters frame in extreme foreground to punch the rewind button on the machine. His hand leaves frame. A few pieces of mail are flipped down onto the machine table, piece by piece, as the machine rewinds. He reaches down again and hits playback. After a beep:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mail continues to flip down onto the table, piece by piece.

direction.raw_text: Dial tone. Beep.

direction.raw_text: The mail stops dropping; Marty has Meurice's attention.

direction.raw_text: His finger presses the stop button.
